summary: A detailed scientific explanation of the Ramachandran Principle and its impact on protein structure, focusing on atomic interactions and dihedral angles.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a title slide introducing the Ramachandran Principle, focusing on protein atomic clashes versus phi and psi angles, accompanied by a molecular structure diagram. The next slide elaborates on the principle, explaining that alpha helices, beta strands, and turns are the most likely conformations for a polypeptide chain due to steric collisions between atoms, illustrated with a colorful protein structure diagram. The third slide delves into the molecular composition, showing a detailed molecular structure with black dots marking a single alanine amino acid and other atoms representing fragments of adjacent residues in a polypeptide chain, highlighting two peptide bonds. The video uses a combination of text and visual aids to explain the Ramachandran Principle and its implications for protein structure, with each slide building upon the previous one to provide a comprehensive understanding of the topic.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker discussing the principle that "two atoms cannot occupy the same space," and explaining its significance in protein structure. He mentions alpha helices, beta sheets, and the avoidance of clashes between atoms as the driving force behind protein's common structures. He then introduces the concept of the Ramachandran principle, stating they will use a small atomic model to understand it.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a detailed 3D molecular model of a polypeptide chain, with atoms represented by spheres of different colors and sizes. The model is set against a gray background, and the atoms are connected by bonds, some of which are highlighted in pink. The text on the right side of the screen explains that black dots mark a single alanine amino acid, while other atoms are fragments of adjacent residues in the polypeptide chain. It also mentions that there are two peptide bonds. The text is in English, with the chemical elements Ca, C, H, N, and O listed at the top. The video includes a cursor moving around the model, highlighting different parts of the structure, and a zoom-in effect on the model to provide a closer view of the molecular details. The overall atmosphere is educational, focusing on the molecular structure and its components.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a single male speaker providing a scientific explanation of an alanine amino acid. He describes the central complete alanine amino acid, distinguishing it from fragments of adjacent amino acids in a polypeptide chain. He points out the main chain or backbone of the polypeptide, and the side chain, specifically the methyl group of the central alanine. He then describes how the central alanine is connected to the other amino acids by peptide bonds. His tone is informative and educational.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a static image of a molecular structure, specifically an amino acid, with a focus on the dihedral angles Phi (Φ) and Psi (Ψ). The molecular model is color-coded, with atoms represented in different colors: carbon (gray), hydrogen (white), oxygen (red), nitrogen (blue), and calcium (black). The Phi and Psi angles are highlighted with green and purple lines, respectively, indicating the rotation around the main-chain bonds. To the right of the molecular structure, there is a text box with the chemical elements "Ca C H N O" at the top, followed by an explanation of the dihedral angles and the rigidity of peptide bonds. The background is a plain gray, and the image is labeled with the software "Jmol" at the bottom left corner. The slide number "4" is visible at the bottom right corner, suggesting this is part of a larger presentation. Throughout the video, there are no changes or movements, maintaining a consistent focus on the molecular structure and the accompanying text.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker, in a calm and informative tone, explaining that in a polypeptide chain, each amino acid has two rotatable bonds, which are part of the backbone. He says that each of these bonds defines "a dihedral or torsion angle," which he promises to explain further, and identifies the two bonds as "phi" and "psi." This is followed by someone saying "lee."

events_list.video_caption: The video features a series of educational slides explaining the concept of dihedral angles in molecular structures, specifically focusing on the phi (Φ) angle. The slides use a 3D molecular model with atoms represented by spheres of different colors and sizes, connected by sticks to illustrate bonds. The first slide introduces the dihedral angle, defined by four atoms, with the phi angle set at 0°. The subsequent slides demonstrate the rotation of the molecule, showing the phi angle changing from 0° to 78°, then to 137°, and finally to 180°, which is equivalent to -180°. The text on the slides explains that clockwise rotation gives dihedral angles from 0° to 180°, while counter-clockwise rotation results in negative angles from -10° to -180°. The final slide shows the phi angle at -71° and -130°, illustrating the negative dihedral angles obtained through counter-clockwise rotation. The background is plain white, and the text is clear and informative, with the molecular model being the central visual element. The video aims to educate viewers on the concept of dihedral angles in chemistry, using visual aids and textual explanations to convey the information effectively.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a single male speaker explaining the concept of a dihedral angle, determined by four atoms, specifically atoms 1 through 4, and how they determine the angle. The speaker's tone is educational and informative. Next, there is a shifting or rotating sound effect, likely illustrating the angle change, as the speaker continues the explanation. Then the speaker continues, describing the rotation around the bond and the angle. The sound effect is repeated.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a slide from a presentation, focusing on the molecular structure of a peptide bond. The slide displays a 3D model of a molecule with atoms represented in different colors, such as red, blue, white, and black, connected by bonds. The model is set against a grey background with a yellow plane highlighting the peptide bond. On the right side of the slide, there is text explaining that peptide bonds hold six atoms in a plane and that most possible angles of Phi (φ) and Psi (ψ) are impossible due to clashes between atoms. The text also mentions that the balls in the model are much smaller than the atoms they represent. The slide includes a legend at the top with the letters "Ca C H N O," indicating the types of atoms present in the molecule. The slide number, 8, is visible in the bottom right corner. Throughout the video, the slide remains static, with no changes in the molecular model or the text.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a single speaker, who appears to be male, stating that "peptide bonds have a double bonded character" and asserting that this prevents rotation. He speaks in a fairly neutral, informative tone.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a slide presentation with a molecular structure diagram on the left side, illustrating a peptide bond with atoms represented by colored spheres. The diagram highlights the angles Phi (Φ) and Psi (Ψ) with green lines and labels, indicating the rotation limitations of these bonds. On the right side, there is a text box with the chemical elements Ca, C, H, N, O listed at the top, followed by an explanation in English about the peptide bond's inability to rotate, holding six atoms in a plane, and the constraints on possible angles due to atom size and clashes. The background is a simple gray, and the slide is numbered 8 in the bottom right corner. Throughout the video, the diagram and text remain static, with no changes in the environment or actions of any individuals.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with speech delivered by a male speaker. He explains that a character resonates with an adjacent oxygen double bond. The speaker mentions that due to an inability to rotate, each peptide bond holds six atoms in a plane. The clip concludes with an indiscernible sound.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a series of slides from a presentation, focusing on molecular structures and their properties. The first slide displays a molecular model with atoms represented by colored spheres, connected by bonds. The atoms are labeled with their chemical symbols (Ca, C, H, N, O), and the slide includes text explaining that peptide bonds hold six atoms in a plane and that most possible angles of Phi (φ) and Psi (ψ) are impossible due to atom size differences. The second slide continues with the molecular model, now highlighting the actual sizes of the atoms, with text stating, "Here are the actual sizes of the atoms." The background of the slides is a neutral gray, and the molecular models are rendered in a 3D format, providing a clear visual representation of the molecular structures. The presentation appears to be educational, likely aimed at students or professionals in the field of chemistry or biology.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker explaining that most angles are impossible due to "clashes between atoms" and that the atoms in the ball and stick model are much smaller than their true sizes. The speaker then clarifies that he is referring to the actual sizes of the atoms, which are called "Van der Waals radii." This speech is followed by a brief, percussive, clanging sound.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a scientific presentation slide that illustrates molecular interactions within a molecule, focusing on the angles of Psi (ψ) and Phi (φ). The slide is divided into two sections: on the left, a 3D molecular model with atoms represented by spheres in various colors, and on the right, a smaller inset image highlighting a "Clash!" between atoms. The text on the slide states, "When Psi (ψ) is fixed at 165°, most Phi (φ) angles produce clashes," with the word "clashes" emphasized in orange. Below the molecular model, the chemical formula "Ca CHN O" is displayed, indicating the elements present in the molecule. The slide also includes a note explaining that the simulation shows clashes while allowing van der Waals overlaps that would be physically impossible. Throughout the video, the molecular model on the left side of the slide undergoes a series of visual changes, with different colored areas appearing and disappearing, indicating varying degrees of molecular interactions or stress points. The inset image on the right remains static, consistently highlighting the clash between atoms. The overall setting is a clean, white background, typical of scientific presentations, with no people or additional environmental details present.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with one male speaker discussing how the psi angle is fixed at 165 degrees, and that the phi angle rotates 360 degrees. The speaker notes how, in the model, atoms get too close, which results in clashes represented by yellow and red objects. When these clashes occur, the speaker explains that the associated phi angle would be impossible when the psi angle is 165 degrees.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a Ramachandran Plot, a graphical representation used in biochemistry to analyze the conformational preferences of amino acid residues in proteins. The plot is displayed on a white background with black dots representing pairs of Phi (φ) and Psi (ψ) dihedral angles that occur in protein structures. These dots cluster into distinct regions labeled as alpha helical (α), beta strand (β), and turn conformations, with areas devoid of dots indicating non-occurring conformations. The axes of the plot are labeled with numerical values ranging from -180 to 180 degrees, representing the range of possible dihedral angles. The plot is accompanied by explanatory text on the left side, providing context and details about the data source and the significance of the plot. Throughout the video, a cursor icon moves across the plot, highlighting specific regions and emphasizing the distribution of dihedral angles within the protein structure. The video serves as an educational tool to illustrate the principles of protein conformation and the importance of Ramachandran plots in structural biology.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio begins with a male speaker introducing a Ramachandran plot and explaining the axes, focusing on phi and psi angles. He describes the data points within the plot, explaining that they represent actual amino acid angles from reliable protein structures. He then points out clusters of dots representing alpha helices, beta strands, and turns. Concluding, he highlights the areas on the plot devoid of data, emphasizing that those confirmations do not occur.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a Ramachandran Plot, a graphical representation used in biochemistry to analyze the conformational properties of protein structures. The plot is divided into regions labeled alpha helix (α), beta strand (β), and turn (γ), with each dot representing a pair of Phi (φ) and Psi (ψ) dihedral angles found in a protein. The plot is accompanied by a molecular model illustrating the Phi angle, with a highlighted region indicating the range of Phi angles that do not cause steric clashes when Psi is fixed at +165°. The text explains that clashes occur at all Phi angles except -70° to -170°, which is within the beta strand region. The molecular model shows a series of atoms connected by bonds, with the Phi angle highlighted in yellow and red, indicating the range of angles that are sterically allowed. The background of the plot is white, with black dots representing the data points and orange lines outlining the regions of allowed conformations. The video provides a clear and detailed visualization of the Ramachandran Plot and its significance in understanding protein structure.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker introducing a rotating phi animation and comparing it to a Ramachandran plot, with a friendly, explanatory tone. He reminds listeners that psi is fixed at 165 degrees and describes how as phi rotates, only one region lacks clashes. He directs attention to the clashes as they appear and mentions that the "no clash region" represents phi angles of -170 to -70 degrees, corresponding to beta strands.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a scientific presentation focusing on molecular structures and their conformational analysis. On the left side of the screen, a 3D molecular model is displayed, with atoms represented by spheres and bonds by sticks. The model highlights specific angles labeled "Phi" and "Psi," which are crucial for understanding the molecule's structure. On the right side, a graph plots these angles, with regions marked as "alpha" (α) and "beta" (β) strands, indicating typical conformations for these secondary structures. The text on the screen explains that "Phi is fixed at -80°" and that "Clashes occur at all Psi angles except +10 to -55° (alpha helix) +90 to 180 (beta strand)." This information is essential for understanding the stability and interactions within the molecule. The video appears to be part of an educational or research presentation, aimed at explaining the principles of molecular geometry and its implications for protein structure. The background is plain, ensuring that the focus remains on the molecular model and the accompanying graph. The presentation is static, with no visible movement or action, emphasizing the educational content over dynamic visuals.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip starts with one male speaker describing an animation involving rotation and fixed angles, mentioning regions with "no clashes." He states that those areas represent certain psi angles, like "alpha helix" and "beta strands." Afterwards, there's a very brief sound akin to a beep.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a scientific presentation focusing on molecular structures and their angles, specifically Phi and Psi. On the left side of the screen, a 3D molecular model is displayed, with atoms represented as spheres and bonds as lines. The model highlights the Psi angle, which is shown in a gradient of colors ranging from red to yellow, indicating its range of motion. On the right side, a graph plots the Psi and Phi angles, with the Phi angle fixed at 0°. The graph shows various regions labeled as "Clashes," "Psi Angles," "alpha," and "beta," indicating different molecular conformations. Text on the screen explains that when Phi is fixed at 0°, clashes occur at all Psi angles, and that Phi = 0° is physically impossible. The background is white, and the overall atmosphere is educational and informative, aimed at explaining the constraints and possibilities of molecular angles in protein structures. The video maintains a consistent visual theme throughout, with no significant changes in the environment or actions of any individuals.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker discussing an animation where he set "phi at zero degrees," which he claims does not occur in real proteins. The speaker observes clashes at all angles, concluding that phi of zero degrees is physically impossible. Following the man's statement, a brief "bleep" or "beep" sound occurs, perhaps indicating the end of the clip or a transition in the audio source.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a slide featuring a 3D model of a protein structure, highlighting the Phi (φ) and Psi (ψ) dihedral angles that determine the conformation of a polypeptide. The slide explains that these angles are limited by steric collisions between atoms, with a note that an angle of 0° is physically impossible. The background is white, and the protein model is colored in yellow, pink, and blue, with a graph in the top right corner. The slide is numbered 14, and the text is in English. The video then transitions to a slide with a white background, displaying a list of links to additional resources, including a quiz, a slideshow version of the video, an interactive 3D tutorial, and more detailed tutorials on the Ramachandran principle and phi/psi angles. The slide also credits Eric Martz for creating the video in July 2018 and mentions the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike 4.0 International license. The slide is numbered 16. The video concludes with a static slide displaying the same information as the previous one, with no changes or movements.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker summarizing the constraints atomic clashes place on combinations of angles. He then offers a quiz and mentions that the tutorial is available as a slideshow. Afterwards, he asks the listener if they would like to have buttons to control rotations, or rotate a molecular model. He ends by stating that these options are available via links below the video.
